pages.text: #resume li:not(:last-child) { padding-bottom: 12px; } Experience Education Computing Skills Publications Harvard Medical School & Massachusetts General Hospital Boston, MA Research Fellow Apr 2015 – Present Developer of TOPAS (Monte Carlo simulation of radiation therapy); improved QA by introducing issue tracking, CI, a custom numerical regression test suite, and code coverage metrics; migrated documentation from a Pages document to a website ; implemented features such as multithreading, enhanced support of patient data files, and output of 2D data structures Devised an algorithm to sample directions within an elliptical cone and verified its uniformity using a two-level Kolmogorov-Smirnov test; this was used to model the incoming proton therapy beams in patient simulations Created models to identify patients whose anatomy permits enhanced benefits from proton therapy, by exploiting knowledge learned from historic treatment plans; this enables better-informed referral decisions at cancer centers without proton therapy capabilities Implemented a custom regression model in scikit-learn and compared the cross-validated accuracy and training/prediction times to a random forest model; models were validated for skull-base (41 patients), lung (104 pts), and prostate (119 pts) cancer cohorts Audited MIT course: 6.036 Introduction to Machine Learning University of Oxford & CERN Oxford, UK & Geneva, Switzerland Postdoctoral Research Assistant Jun 2014 – Mar 2015 Team leader of 5 CERN physicists to infer the underlying kinematics of the Higgs boson by deconvolving detector effects using an iterative Bayesian approach Organized weekly meetings to review the latest results from each team member, identify potential problems, and delegate duties for future work Software Coordinator for the ATLAS Monte Carlo Group, which involved developing new features and interfacing C++/Python code with external C++ and Fortran libraries Liased with Software Coordinators of other key groups and the Release Manager to deliver an operational simulation framework before Run 2 of the Large Hadron Collider Arbtree Research Ltd Oxford, UK Consultant Physicist Oct 2014 – Mar 2015 Developed audio recognition algorithms for a novel integrated device University of Oxford & CERN Oxford, UK & Geneva, Switzerland Doctoral Student Oct 2010 – Jun 2014 Core team member of the flagship search for the Higgs boson at the Large Hadron Collider Processed petabytes of empirical and simulated data with worldwide distributed computing Built a statistical model describing the contributions from signal and background processes, as constrained and validated by observations in "control regions" Devised and validated new techniques that contributed to a 50% improvement in the expected Z -score (the most sensitive standalone measurement of the Higgs boson to date); pages.title: Including YAML files within YAML files
pages.text: This blog entry has been copied from my particle physics blog I have written an extension to the PyYAML Loader class that allows you to include/import YAML files from within another YAML file. I'm currently writing a program that will data from a YAML file and create a CV using a template engine. To aid flexibility, I wanted to allow the user to be able to include separate YAML files (e.g. education.yaml, skills.yaml, etc) within a master YAML file which would then be used to make the CV. An initial search found this , which allows users to include a YAML file from within another. However, it's quite a limited solution – it assumes you only want to include a single file. For my CV program, I wanted to be able to include multiple files within a single section. This could let you have separate files containing publications according to subject, and then include different groups of publications for different CVs. My solution now supports all three kinds of YAML node: scalar, sequence and mapping. The class could alternatively derive from yaml.CLoader for improved performance when the C++ LibYAML bindings are available. import yaml import os.path class Loader ( yaml . Loader ): def __init__ ( self , stream ): self . _root = os . path . split ( stream . name )[ 0 ] super ( Loader , self ) . __init__ ( stream ) Loader . add_constructor ( '!include' , Loader . include ) Loader . add_constructor ( '!import' , Loader . include ) def include ( self , node ): if isinstance ( node , yaml . ScalarNode ): return self . extractFile ( self . construct_scalar ( node )) elif isinstance ( node , yaml . SequenceNode ): result = [] for filename in self . construct_sequence ( node ): result += self . extractFile ( filename ) return result elif isinstance ( node , yaml . MappingNode ): result = {} for k , v in self . construct_mapping ( node ) . iteritems (): result [ k ] = self . extractFile ( v ) return result else : print "Error:: unrecognised node type in !include statement" raise yaml . constructor . ConstructorError def extractFile ( self , filename ): filepath = os . path . join ( self . _root , filename ) with open ( filepath , 'r' ) as f : return yaml . load ( f , Loader ) Please note that the arguments to !include and !import must be on the same line (due to PyYAML parser). This allows you to specify YAML files like: education : !include education.yaml activities : !include [ schools.yaml , conferences.yaml , workshops.yaml ] publications : !include { peer_reviewed : publications/peer_reviewed.yaml , internal : publications/internal.yaml } This Loader class is passed to yaml.load() like so: from yaml import load with open ( 'document.yaml' , 'r' ) as f : data = load ( f , Loader = Loader )
